extracted_key_facts: In late May 2005, a popular uprising against foreign domination occurred in the Maghreb region, specifically the Western Sahara.
The uprising involved ethnic Sahrawis demanding the withdrawal of Moroccan troops and independence for the Western Sahara, a former Spanish colony occupied by Morocco since 1975.
The Sahrawis are calling their resistance an Intifada, or “shaking off”.
The Harakah Al-Tahrir Al-Sahra’ (Movement of Liberation of the Sahara) led by Mohammed Sidi Ibrahim Bassiri was the first organization to call for Western Sahara’s independence in 1967.
In June 1970, Spanish colonial forces dispersed a demonstration in Al-‘Ayun, killing at least a dozen Sahrawis, an event known as the Intifada Zemla.
The Frente Popular para la Liberación de Saguia el-Hamra y Río de Oro (Polisario) was formed in 1973.
In November 1975, the Madrid Accords divided the Western Sahara between Morocco and Mauritania, without consulting the Sahrawi population.
Moroccan forces moved into the Western Sahara in 1975, accompanied by 350,000 Moroccan “civilian volunteers”.
Following the Moroccan invasion, most ethnic Sahrawis fled to refugee camps in Tindouf, southern Algeria.
The Polisario fought against Moroccan and Mauritanian forces, receiving arms and aid from Algeria and Libya.

By 1982 Mauritanian troops had been defeated and Moroccan control was reduced to a bare 15% of the territory, but the U.S., France, and Saudi Arabia increased support for Morocco, helping them build an 800-mile sand-wall.
By the late 1980s, the conflict became a military stalemate, dividing Western Sahara into a Moroccan-controlled section (80%) and a Polisario section.
In 1988, Morocco and the Polisario agreed to hold an independence-or-integration referendum under UN auspices.
In 1992, UN peacekeepers were deployed to the Western Sahara to monitor the ceasefire and to prepare the population for a referendum, but the referendum never took place.
In 2000, the UN Security Council decided against a referendum, and Moroccan intransigence foiled mediation efforts.
The Moroccan government implemented a “Moroccanization” policy to assimilate Sahrawis, offering jobs and housing in Morocco.
Since the death of Moroccan King Hassan II in July 1999 and the ascension of his son King Mohammed VI, Morocco experienced some political liberalization.
In September and October 1999, social discontent erupted in Al-‘Ayun, leading to demonstrations by Sahrawi students and former political prisoners.
In May 2005, Morocco triggered the second Sahrawi Intifada by transferring a Sahrawi prisoner, leading to widespread demonstrations and a violent crackdown.
By early January 2006, Aminatou Haidar, a Sahrawi activist known as the “Sahrawi Gandhi,” was released from prison.
Since 1975, Morocco has restricted media access to the Western Sahara.
As of November 2005, King Mohammed declared Morocco was willing to offer the Western Sahara “enhanced autonomy” under Moroccan sovereignty.
As of 2005, the Polisario was considering resuming armed struggle if UN led peace talks continued to stagnate.

extracted_key_facts: Josephine Baker, an African-American woman who became a French citizen, worked as a spy for the Allies during the German occupation of France in World War II.
Baker used her celebrity and diplomatic connections to gather information from embassies in Paris, including those of Italy and Japan.
Jacques Abtey, an officer of the Deuxième Bureau (French military intelligence), recruited Josephine Baker as an Honorable Correspondent to gather information.
Baker sheltered refugees, including Belgians and fellow entertainers, at her castle, Les Milandes, near the Dordogne River.
In June 1940, France was occupied by the Germans, leading to the establishment of Vichy France.

Baker carried confidential information about German troop movements written in invisible ink on her sheet music and hidden in her clothing.

During 1941, Baker traveled between Morocco, Portugal, and Les Milandes, collecting information and performing concerts to fund her activities.
Baker had contacts in Morocco, including Thami el Glaoui (pasha of Marrakech), Moulay Larbi el Alaoui (cousin of the Sultan), and Si Mohammed Menebhi.
Ahmed Ben Bachir helped Baker obtain Spanish-Moroccan passports for Jewish refugees fleeing from Spain.
In June 1941, Baker was admitted to the Comte clinic in Morocco with peritonitis, which incapacitated her for 19 months.
While hospitalized in Morocco, Baker's room was used for clandestine meetings between Abtey and American contacts to exchange information.
In 1943, Baker began singing for African-American troops at the Liberty Club in Morocco and promoting Charles de Gaulle as the future leader of Free France.
Baker toured North Africa, offering concerts and advocating for De Gaulle, traveling with Jacques Abtey and Si Mohammed Menebhi.
Charles de Gaulle awarded Baker the Croix de Lorraine for her service.
Baker was appointed sub-lieutenant of the Women's Auxiliary Corps of the French Air Force in 1944 for her propaganda services in the Middle East.
On October 14, 1946, Baker received the Medal of the Resistance from Charles de Gaulle.
